content: @WG-async-foundations meeting!
wave
Let's see
there's one issue for triage, maybe we'll talk about that and then do updates
ICE: Broken MIR: generator contains type Vec<[u8; 16]> in MIR, but typeck only knows about X, Y, Z #88171
so there's an inference var for the array length when we check what types the generator contains
it records Vec<[u8; _]> but the final type is Vec<[u8; 16]>
I guess.. if we are able to type check this successfully, that means the inference var can take any value?
uh
..assuming there's not another bug in typeck somewhere
I ... something is fishy here
It seems like maybe typeck wasn't able to infer the length, but on the path to MIR somehow it discovered a length for it?
this feels like it may be a const generics bug
^ yeah
wait, I'm confused about whether we expect to have full type information for locals when we do the generator HIR analysis
it seems like we should, that's sort of the point
but last week we were talking about having to tweak the liveness pass because full type info isn't available
(if we were going to use it for the generator analysis)
I think I'm just conflating the different stages of typeck in my head
well
this error comes much later
I don't know how we are getting out of typeck with an uninferred variable
seems weird
ah, I wonder
this might be a "delay span bug" situation
well, I guess not
not sure! would have to dig in
I would not categorize this as high priority though
well the generator pass captures the type with uninferred vars during typeck, right
uh
I forget
I don't know, but I'd sort of expect these variables to get filled in later.
later than what :)
I would expect type check to resolve them
later than the generator_interior analysis. it happens as part of type check, iirc, ergo type check is not complete when it runs
so
I'm not sure what generator-liveness is but
wait, there's generator_liveness? Or do you mean generator_interior?
this error comes very late, after MIR building is complete
this error occurs during MIR lowering
oh, I guess I see your point

eholk said:

wait, there's generator_liveness? Or do you mean generator_interior?

that's what I meant, I was just thinking that was wrong
yor point is that: the place where we record the types that may be used in generator comes too early?
I guess I just have to review the code, but I would expect it to share type variables
that get inferred to a final value during writeback or something
maybe I'm forgetting some aspect of this
okay
that was my point, yeah

nikomatsakis said:

that get inferred to a final value during writeback or something

that sounds plausible
in any case we should probably mark this as triaged and let const generics handle it
it should be handled, somehow, for regular types or we would have seen it before
okay, done
Updates
/me types
@nikomatsakis and I have been working on organizing the roadmap better, and are converging on an "Area > Initiative > Milestone" hierarchy
where areas are the headings on the existing roadmap, e.g. "async fn everywhere", "polish"
and initiatives are bundles of deliverables that are interconnected in some way
you can see a preview at https://nikomatsakis.github.io/wg-async-foundations/vision/roadmap.html
a big part of this is working towards declaring the final set of "deliverable areas" and owner(s) for each one
here's an example of an initiative with the milestones that are part of it
we're thinking that area owners should define these
one thing we talked about is putting together a guide on being an area owner
we don't have to cover all of that here
Having a guide would be helpful for me, but I'm also happy to ask questions and stumble through things.
I plan to do that today and get a fresh draft up
the other thing is
@tmandry and I were talking about how to organize the other content as well
https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-async-foundations/pull/230 is an attempt to realize some of those ideas
the idea is to collect a set of representative projects

• [DistriData]: High-performance "cloud service" that stores data on behalf of clients in a reliable and highly scalable fashion.
  • [MonsterMesh]: Networking in an "extreme embedded" environment like IoT sensors.
  • [SLOW]: A library that lives on crates.io and implements a (fictituous) networking protocol called "SLOW"; the library is meant to be used in most "normal" environments (i.e., not necessarily an extreme embedded environment like MonsterMesh).
  • [YouBuy]: An e-commerce website, similar to what one might build with Ruby on Rails.
and then have a status quo / shiny future narrative for each one
that complements the User's Guide for the future
I started working some on the outline of the distridata one
which is cribbing a lot from the AWS engineer story but also other stories we received
one thing I realized is that I actually don't know very well e.g. what the life of someone writing async rust in emebedded land is like
I was talking to @Dario Nieuwenhuis about the idea of helping to work on the "MonsterMesh" story
I'd be interested in landing this PR and other people picking up these stories (or altering them...) and running a bit with them
ah, one other aspect, is that we called out the problems we see
rendered form
So the idea is that we'd merge all the status quo stories that talk about e.g. DistriData into a single DistriData narrative?
not exactly
the idea is that we use these four stories to highlight and explain the problems
each can use the different characters to show things that are specific to people's background
and we choose the story that best illustrates the problem, or have it show up in multiple places
but the original story doesn't have to have been targeting that particular sort of probelm
as an example, there are problems around doing zero-copy network reads, or use io-uring, I think that shows up in the MonsterMesh story beacuse it's hard to use DMA
I'm not sure if it needs to show up elsewhere or not
(I'm not opposed)
does that make sense?
is the primary value you see consolidating all the many stories into four canonical ones, so they're more approachable / less overwhelming?
yes
there may not be value in it
that is, mabe it's nicer to have vignettes?
I think combining the stories is a good idea
but I .. well, yes, I guess I think that ultimately it will be better
but it's going to take some work to get it there
I spent the better part of a week reading all the stories, so it'd be nice to have a more condensed version.
I admit I find the list of stories we have overwhelming :-)
one thing I did already notice is that it encourages us to explore areas we may not have deeply explored (embedded)
it's not just being condensed
it's also that I want to be sure we have an end-to-end story
like: what is the experience like of learning async rust all the way from learning it to putting X into production
I was thinking maybe something like we a DistriData story about a team of our four characters and we talk about the challenges each of them face.
where X is one of those kinds of systems

eholk said:

I was thinking maybe something like we a DistriData story about a team of our four characters and we talk about the challenges each of them face.

right
I was intended something like that
though I thought of them as interwoven

nikomatsakis said:

like: what is the experience like of learning async rust all the way from learning it to putting X into production

and what parts did we ultimately fail to explore
there is at least one use case that is not on that list that, indeed, I think we barely explored
which is using a "ruby on rails" like setup
I'm thinking of eg. rocket
what's that like? what's missing?
I sort of like the idea of having stories that we can reference as "canon" that everyone knows about
yes
it will be nice for the future
what confused me until recently
but I'm feeling good about lately
I often wanted the characters to the central thing
"you're messing it up for Barbara if you do that!"
and sometimes that might be true
but I think having the "projects" be the central axis maybe works better
there are just two axes however you slice it
anyway I like the project setup, with the same characters across them,
it also feels like it will work if we do vision docs in other domains

tmandry said:

it will be nice for the future

I'm imagining future async conversations being like "as Barbara says in the async tomes of old..."
Yeah, combining the characters into a single story will be nice. There are a lot of cases to say things like "Niklaus goes down the hall and asks Barbara for help."
okay, well
I have a bit of time
we've said before that we want to do sprints starting in early september, which is pretty soon :)
I'm going to polish up this PR with the roadmap changes and get it up
but I just noticed @eholk you have some open PRs?

tmandry said:

we've said before that we want to do sprints starting in early september, which is pretty soon :)

lol yes!
Yeah, I have a couple of late stories to add
^ yes, I'm really glad for those, I think they were a missing piece

I think the status quo one is ready to go. The shiny future could use an example command line session for what debugging would look like in the future, but I'd kind of rather merge the story as is and maybe add the debugging session later.
I don't really have enough experience using debuggers yet to imagine what that should look like.
sounds good to me

tmandry said:

we've said before that we want to do sprints starting in early september, which is pretty soon :)

I don't really see us finishing up the canonical stories before then, do you @nikomatsakis? so I guess that will be a parallel track
I agree
I see them as evolving over time anyway
Apparently Visual Studio has amazing async debugging tools for C#, so I might go write some buggy C# code and get some practice debugging it.
it's a good point that we should record that work item
well, we definitely won't have them finished. we might have some of them drafted by then :P
okay, anything else on this?
@triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
and if not, are there other things people want to talk about?
I'm making some progress experimenting with liveness for generator_interior. I don't think the current approach will work as is, but it's giving me ideas
We can talk about that in the other topic though if people are interested.
ok
I'm sort of interested to talk about async overloading :)
but I'd start a topic for it
@Yoshua Wuyts has been thinking about async overloading lately
okay sounds good, we can talk about those things in their own topics
@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
well this is a bit slow
I think we're done anyway
thanks all!
Thanks!
